QUESTION: which of the following is not an adverse effect of salbutamol?
OPTIONS:
a) Tachycardia
b) Tolerance
c) Hypokalemia
d) Hypoglycemia
SOLUTION:
salbutamol in large doses can result in hyperglycemia, not hypoglycemia.
option A: Tachycardia due to reflex sympathetic stimulation due to vasodilator action on β2 receptors and direct effect on cardiac β1 receptors (β2 selectivity is lost at high concentrations) option B: Tolerance occurs due to desensitization on long-term use
option C: Hypokalemia due to direct effect on skeletal muscle uptake of K+ ions

QUESTION: propranolol is drug of choice for:
OPTIONS:
a) ulcerated infantile hemangioma
b) Lymphangioma circumscriptum
c) capillary malformation
d) pyogenic granuloma
SOLUTION:
propranolol is the drug of choice in the management of infantile hemangioma complicated by ulceration or in symptomatic patients.
It acts by causing vasoconstriction, inducing apoptosis and inhibition of angiogenesis.

QUESTION: cIostridium difficile associated diarrhea occurs maximally due to:
OPTIONS:
a) Lincosamides
b) Tetracyclines
c) carbapenems
d) Macrolide
SOLUTION:
clostridium difficile-associated diarrhea is mostly due to lincosamides such as clindamycin
Antibiotic-associated colitis is caused by clostridium difficile infection due to the destruction of the normal gut microbial flora by the use of antibiotics. The antibiotics most frequently implicated include clindamycin, fluoroquinolones and broad-spectrum penicillins, and cephalosporins
clostridium difficile infection occurs frequently in hospitals and nursing homes where antimicrobial use is high and the environment is contaminated by c. difficile spores.
Although all antibiotics can cause the condition, the most commonly implicated are:
• clindamycin
• Third-generation cephalosporins (cefotaxime, ceftriaxone, cefuroxime, and ceftazidime)
• Fluoroquinolones (ciprofloxacin, levofloxacin, and moxifloxacin)
• Broad-spectrum penicillins

QUESTION: A 53 year old man is found to have stage 2 hypertension without any co morbidities. which drug will you start?
OPTIONS:
a) Furosemide
b) chlorthalidone
c) spironolactone
d) Triamterene
SOLUTION:
chlorthalidone is one of the first choice drugs in the treatment of hypertension without any comorbidities.
First-choice drugs used in the treatment of hypertension in patients without any comorbidities include:
• Thiazide diuretics: chlorthalidone is usually preferred to hydrochlorothiazide.
• calcium channel blockers: Extended-release, long-acting dihydropyridines are preferred.
• AcE inhibitors: captopril is preferred for the initiation of therapy. Enalapril and ramipril twice daily may also be used.
In the presence of any associated conditions or comorbidities, the first choice drugs for the treatment of hypertension would be as follows:
conditions associated with h ypertension: Diabetes, chronic kidney disease with proteinuria; Angina; Heart failure; Benign prostatic hyperplasia; Pregnancy; Atrial fibrillation
First choice drugs for hyperte nsion: Inhibitors of renin-angiotensi n system.; Beta-blockers or calcium cha nnel blockers; AcE inhibitors and alpha+be ta blockers such as carvedilol; α1Blockers; Labetalol; Diltiazem and verapamil

QUESTION: which of the following is a schedule X drug?
OPTIONS:
a) Halothane
b) Thalidomide
c) ketamine
d) colistin
SOLUTION:
ketamine is a schedule X drug.
According to The Drugs and cosmetics Act-1945,
schedule X drugs are those that have high abuse liability and are to be sold with a valid prescription only.
A prescription in duplicate, separate license requirement, meticulous storage, and dispensing records must be maintained by the chemist.
option B: Thalidomide is a schedule H drug.
option D: colistin is a schedule P drug.

QUESTION: LMwH is given by which route?
OPTIONS:
a) Intravenous
b) subcutaneous
c) Intramuscular
d) Intradermal
SOLUTION:
LMWH is given by the subcutaneous route.
Heparin, low molecular weight heparin (LMWH), and fondaparinux are not absorbed through GI mucosa and must be given parenterally.
LMWH and fondaparinux are given subcutaneously.
Heparin can be given through intravenous infusion and subcutaneous routes.

QUESTION: A patient presents to the emergency department with diarrhea, sweating, excessive lacrimation, and salivation. His pulse rate is 55/min and his plasma cholinesterase level was 5ou/mL. which of the following can be used to treat this patient?
OPTIONS:
a) Neostigmine
b) Atropine
c) Epinephrine
d) Benztropine
SOLUTION:
The clinical features are suggestive of organophosphate poisoning and IV atropine is the treatment of choice.
The organophosphates commonly used as pesticides are anticholinesterases. Toxicity occurs by excessive inhalation of vapors, ingestion, or percutaneous absorption. It inhibits the cholinesterase activity which results in an increase of acetylcholine, leading to cholinergic symptoms.
The predominant initial signs are of muscarinic excess which includes: (DUMBBELSS)
• Diarrhea
• Urination
• Miosis
• Bronchospasm
• Bradycardia
• Emesis
• Lacrimation
• Salivation
• Sweating
This may be followed by cognitive disturbances, convulsions, and neuromuscular blockade.
Treatment:
• Maintenance of vital signs particularly respiration
• Removal of clothing and washing of the skin
• IV atropine 2- 5 mg. If IV administration is not possible, then 2 mg IM every 5-1o minutes (till muscarinic symptoms disappear)
• pralidoxime, a cholinesterase reactivator can also be used for treatment

QUESTION: what is pegloticase used for?
OPTIONS:
a) chronic gout
b) Rheumatoid arthritis
c) psoriatric arthritis
d) paralytic ileus
SOLUTION:
pegloticase is used in the treatment of chronic gout.
pegloticase is a pegylated uricase (urate oxidase). It catalyzes the enzymatic oxidation of uric acid into allantoin, which is a more soluble and inactive metabolite.
It is used in the treatment of severe, refractory chronic gout or in cases where other urate-lowering therapies are contraindicated.

QUESTION: which of the following GpcRs does not act via the K+ channel?
OPTIONS:
a) Angiotensin 1 receptor
b) Muscarinic M2 receptor
c) Dopamine D2 receptor
d) serotonin 5 HT1 receptor
SOLUTION:
Angiotensin 1 receptor acts via ca2+ channels. It does not act through second messengers via the K+ channel.
G-protein coupled receptors activate inwardly rectifying potassium channels and increase the permeability of the potassium ions causing hyperpolarisation of the cell. They are called G protein-coupled inwardly-rectifying potassium channels (GIRKs). These receptors include:
• M2 muscarinic
• A1 adenosine
• α2 adrenergic
• D2 dopamine
• 5HT1 serotonin
• Somatostatin receptors.

QUESTION: which of the following is not used in heart failure?
OPTIONS:
a) Trimetazidine
b) sacubitril
c) Metoprolol
d) Nesiritide
SOLUTION:
Trimetazidine is not used in heart failure.
Trimetazidine is a newer antianginal drug that is a pFOX inhibitor which partially inhibits the fatty acid oxidation pathway in the myocardium. This decreases the oxygen requirement of the heart.
Nesiritide (natriuretic peptide), sacubitril (neprilysin inhibitor) and metoprolol (beta-blocker) are used in the treatment of heart failure.

QUESTION: which of the following causes an increase in Ach release from the presynaptic neuron?
OPTIONS:
a) potassium channel blocker
b) sodium channel blocker
c) calcium channel blocker
d) chlorine channel blocker
SOLUTION:
potassium channel blockers cause an increase in Ach release from the presynaptic neuron.
presynaptic potassium channel block promotes the activation of voltage-gated calcium channels. This leads to a release of acetylcholine in the neuromuscular junction.
Aminopyridines (k+ channel blockers) are used in the treatment of Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome which helps to improve muscle strength.

QUESTION: Apart from mu-opioid receptors, on which other receptor does tramadol act?
OPTIONS:
a) Anticholinergic
b) 5HT1a inhibition
c) serotonergic and norepinephrine reuptake inhibition
d) Antihistaminic
SOLUTION:
Tramadol inhibits the reuptake of serotonin and norepinephrine, apart from its action on the mu-opioid receptor.
It is a synthetic codeine analog that is a mu-opioid receptor agonist.
Tramadol is a centrally acting analgesic used in the treatment of mild to moderate pain.

QUESTION: In which of the following conditions is non-pulsatile dosing of GnRH agonist not used?
OPTIONS:
a) Male infertility
b) Endometriosis
c) precocious puberty
d) prostate cancer
SOLUTION:
pulsatile dose of GnRH agonist is used in the treatment of male infertility.
pulsatile administration of GnRH agonists results in increased FSH and LH secretion and is used to treat male and female infertility.
Non-pulsatile or continuous dose of GnRH agonist results in suppression and decreased concentrations of gonadotropins LH and FSH. They are used in:
• Endometriosis
• uterine fibroids
• central precocious puberty
• ca prostate
• ca ovary and breast
• controlled ovary stimulation

QUESTION: which of the following cannot be used to decrease intraocular pressure in glaucoma?
OPTIONS:
a) Dexamethasone
b) Acetazolamide
c) Apraclonidine
d) Mannitol
SOLUTION:
Dexamethasone is a long-acting glucocorticoid and is not used to decrease the intraocular pressure in glaucoma.
Acetazolamide, apraclonidine, and mannitol are used in lowering intraocular pressure in glaucoma.

QUESTION: prucalopride is a ______.
OPTIONS:
a) 5HT2a agonist
b) 5HT2b agonist
c) 5HT4 antagonist
d) 5HT4 agonist
SOLUTION:
prucalopride is a specific 5HT4 receptor agonist which increases bowel movements.
It is approved for use in women with chronic constipation where other laxatives have failed to provide relief.

QUESTION: Z track technique is used for?
OPTIONS:
a) Administration of nicotine patches
b) Monitoring of carbamazepine therapy
c) Administration of long acting depot antipsychotics
d) Monitoring of lithium therapy
SOLUTION:
The Z-track technique is used for the intramuscular administration of long-acting depot antipsychotics.
Advantages:
• The 'Z-track' prevents leakage of the medication into the subcutaneous tissue and skin staining through the tract to the surface of the skin
• pain intensity is also reduced

QUESTION: Tafenoquine is used in which of the following conditions?
OPTIONS:
a) Radical cure of plasmodium vivax
b) prophylaxis of malaria in pregnancy
c) Treatment of severe falciparum malaria
d) Treatment of malaria in children <2 years
SOLUTION:
Tafenoquine is used in the radical cure of Plasmodium vivax. Total eradication of plasmodium species which includes clinical curative and hypnozoites phase are called radical cure.
Primaquine and tafenoquine (derivative of primaquine) have very high activity against the latent tissue forms (hypnozoites) of the species. It is primarily used for the chemoprophylaxis and radical cure of P. vivax and P. ovale infections.

QUESTION: which is not given in wilson's disease?
OPTIONS:
a) zinc
b) penicillamine
c) calcium citrate
d) Trientine
SOLUTION:
calcium citrate is not used in the treatment of wilson's disease.
The drugs used in the management of wilson's disease are:
chelating agents: These drugs bind to copper to form complexes that get excreted in the urine. D-penicillamine and trientine are first-line drugs in symptomatic patients with hepatic diseases.
• D-penicillamine: It is the recommended drug due to its availability and cost-effectiveness as compared to trientine. since it is an antagonist to pyridoxine, supplementation of pyridoxine is required. It can precipitate various adverse effects including aplastic anemia, myasthenia gravis, and membranous nephropathy. It can also worsen neurological symptoms
• Trientine: It is administered in those who cannot tolerate D-penicillamine
• Tetrathiomolybdate: It has been identified to be effective in patients with neuropsychiatric manifestation
Elemental zinc:
• zinc blocks the intestinal absorption of copper by inducing metallothionein (endogenous chelator in enterocytes)
• It is commonly used as a maintenance therapy along with chelating agents. It can also be used as first-line therapy in pregnancy

QUESTION: what dose of epinephrine is used in anaphylactic shock?
OPTIONS:
a) 1:1oooo I.V. - 1o ml
b) 1:1ooo I.M. - o.5 ml
c) 1:1ooo I.M. - 1 ml
d) 1:1ooo I.V. - o.5 ml
SOLUTION:
Epinephrine (1:1ooo solution) o.5 ml via intramuscular route is preferred in the treatment of anaphylactic shock.
For intravenous use, 1:1ooo adrenaline must be further diluted to 1:1o,ooo and should be used very cautiously as slow bolus.
There is a much greater risk of causing harmful side effects by either inappropriate dosage or misdiagnosis of anaphylaxis when using IV adrenaline. Hence, IM injection is preferred over intravenous (IV) bolus because it is faster in many situations and safer (lower risk of cardiovascular complications, such as severe hypertension and ventricular arrhythmias).
For intramuscular, subcutaneous, and inhalational (nebulization) routes of administration, 1:1ooo dilution can be used.
In cardiac arrest, the 1:1ooo adrenaline must be diluted to 1:1o,ooo for IV use. The recommended dose of epinephrine is 1mg 〓 1o mL of 1:1o,ooo solution IV administered every 3 to 5 minutes during resuscitation as per the CPR guidelines.
Epinephrine is also used in the treatment of hypotension, to induce local vasoconstriction to reduce the diffusion of local anaesthetics and to induce bronchodilation in asthma and COPD.

QUESTION: which of the following is true about tedizolid?
OPTIONS:
a) Active against gram positive organisms
b) poor oral bioavailability
c) Active against anaerobes
d) causes peripheral neuropathy
SOLUTION:
Tedizolid is active against gram-positive organisms.
Tedizolid belongs to the class of oxazolidinones. It has poor activity against most gram-negative bacteria and anaerobes. It inhibits protein synthesis by binding to the P site of the 5oS ribosomal subunit.
It is used for the treatment of skin and soft tissue infections, respiratory tract infections caused by streptococci, and S. aureus including MRSA.
Common adverse effects include myelosuppression leading to anemia, leukopenia, thrombocytopenia, and pancytopenia.
